marketNews.title: The Fed Indicates Delay in US Rate Cuts, Rupiah Weakens
marketNews.content:
The Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled that the start of U.S. interest rate cuts will take longer than expected as inflation remains above forecasts and the labor market stays strong. Powell also said that if inflation pressure continues, the Fed may keep rates unchanged for as long as needed.

In March 2024, the United States recorded inflation of 3.5% year-over-year (versus February 2024: 3.2%), exceeding the consensus expectation of 3.4%. This marks the third consecutive month that inflation has been higher than expected.

The inflation pressure reinforces the narrative that U.S. rates will stay at a high level for a longer period (“higher for longer”). According to the CME FedWatch Tool, the probability of a Fed rate cut at the June 2024 meeting fell sharply from 61.1% on 2 April 2024 to 15.2% on 17 April 2024.

The market currently expects the Fed to begin cutting rates only in Q3 2024, with only one to two cuts throughout the year. Previously, the Fed projected three rate cuts in 2024.

The “higher for longer” narrative also affected Indonesia, with the rupiah weakening to as low as 16,300 per US dollar on the morning of Wednesday 17 April. Bank Indonesia intervened in the spot and non-deliverable forward markets to maintain exchange-rate stability.

In October 2023, Bank Indonesia unexpectedly raised the BI Rate by 25 basis points after the rupiah fell to 15,860, the weakest level since April 2020.

Key Takeaway

The Fed’s signal to postpone U.S. rate cuts could lower expectations for a BI Rate cut. Bloomberg-surveyed economists still project that Bank Indonesia will start cutting its policy rate in Q3 2024.

The “higher for longer” narrative may negatively impact interest-rate-sensitive sectors such as banking, property, and technology. Conversely, a stronger US dollar could benefit exporters such as ITMG, ADRO, INKP, TKIM, MYOR, and ICBP.

Indonesian government bond yields also rose as expectations of sustained high rates persisted, with the 10-year sovereign yield up 58 basis points year-to-date. Investors may lock in more attractive yields on FR bonds held to maturity, for example FR0097 which yielded 7.05% per annum as of 17 April 2024. FR bonds can be purchased via Bibit.

marketNews.title: TINS Targets Up to 75% YoY Revenue Growth in 2024
marketNews.content:
• TINS: The company’s corporate secretary, Abdullah Umar, said TINS aims for revenue growth of 70-75% year-over-year in 2024. To achieve this, TINS will push export sales as the London Metal Exchange tin price has risen 25.2% year-to-date. TINS targets production of 30,000 tonnes in 2024, roughly double the 2023 realization.

• ARCI: Archi Indonesia announced that mining activities at one of the pits owned by its subsidiaries PT Meares Soputan Mining and PT Tambang Tondano Nusajaya were temporarily halted due to flooding and landslides caused by more than 24 hours of heavy rain in North Minahasa Regency and Bitung City, North Sulawesi on 6-7 April 2024. The event may disrupt pit operations and cash flow during the remediation period.

• TMAS: Temas’ corporate secretary, Marthala Vigita, stated that the company targets new contract growth of 8-10% year-over-year in 2024, with revenue expected to rise 16.3% year-over-year to IDR 5 trillion. For 2024, TMAS allocates capex of IDR 1.3 trillion (up from IDR 1 trillion in 2023), with 20-30% earmarked for decarbonisation business expansion through its subsidiary PT Temas Energy.

• META: PT Metro Pacific Tollways Indonesia announced an extension of the voluntary tender offer period until 17 May 2024, 16:00 WIB. Previously, the tender offer ran from 19 March to 17 April 2024. Payments to shareholders who submitted tender forms by 17 April 2024 will still be made on 24 April 2024.

• DOID: Delta Dunia Makmur reported that its subsidiary BUMA Australia Pty. Ltd. signed a contract with Blackwater Operations Pty. Ltd. to provide pre-strip mining services. The contract value was not disclosed. DOID expects the contract to contribute significantly to BUMA Australia’s revenue up to June 2026, with an average annual overburden removal of about 36 million cubic metres.

Bank Indonesia reported that retail sales in Indonesia grew 1.7% month-over-month and 6.4% year-over-year in February 2024 (versus January 2024: –3.5% MoM and +1.1% YoY), supported by increased activity during the Chinese New Year, elections, and Ramadan preparations. The central bank forecasts retail sales to grow 4.1% MoM and 3.5% YoY in March 2024.

Bank Indonesia announced that the Consumer Confidence Index rose to 123.8 in March 2024 (versus 123.1 in February 2024).

Energy and Mineral Resources Minister Arifin Tasrif set the average Indonesian Crude Price (ICP) for March 2024 at USD 83.79 per barrel, up USD 3.69 per barrel from February 2024, driven by potential global supply tightening following attacks on Russian refineries and a decline in US crude inventories in mid-March 2024.

Apple CEO Tim Cook said the company will explore the possibility of building a manufacturing facility in Indonesia. Apple currently produces most iPads, AirPods, Apple Watch, and MacBooks in Vietnam.

Kontan reported that the government plans to grant mining licences (IUP) to community organisations through a revision of Government Regulation No. 96 of 2021.

The Ministry of Trade revised Permendag No. 36 of 2023 on import policy. Under the new Permendag No. 3 of 2024, the government no longer limits the quantity and type of goods brought in from abroad. Instead, it caps the maximum value of goods at USD 1,500 per year to be exempt from import duties, VAT, luxury tax, and income tax.
